title: Man finds terrifying 'advice' sheet after checking into 'run down' hotel on holiday
text:
Man finds terrifying 'advice' sheet after checking into 'run down' hotel on holiday He said he'd never had it at any other hotel anywhere else in the world Share The hotel (not pictured) offered advice unlike any other (Photo: Photolibrary RM) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
What's the first thing you do when you check into a hotel room? 
Usually it's testing out how comfortable the bed is, seeing if the TV works and checking if there's a kettle in the room - after all, Brits can't be away from their cups of tea. 
Refer to the hotel's advice pamphlets and you might learn where to find the gym or if room service is served 24 hours. 
What you don't want to see on these leaflets is advice on what to do in the most terrifying situation imaginable. 
One man, known only as Matt on social media, was on a short break in Russia to watch his team Manchester United play - but was shocked by the reading material in his hotel room advising what to do if he was taken hostage or kidnapped. 
Gulp. 
Naturally, it's not the most comforting thing to see when you're in a foreign country. 
The sheet read: "While kidnapping do not resist. Execute the initial orders of terrorits. They can be people with unhealthy state of mind and behave unpredictable. 
"Try to get into a contact with terrorists/ Try to keep in mind how they look like, their habits, how and with whom they speak to. 
"Try to remember all movements, including the time in motion, direction, distance, speed, any reference points along the road." 
That's a lot of stuff to remember when you're being held hostage. The advice seems to be a normal thing for guests at the hotel (Photo: Getty) 
Still, it's better to be safe than sorry, right? 
Matt told other Twitter users that the unidentified hotel was "very run down but the people so far are very pleasant" and that he hadn't seen any trouble. 
The tweet has since been shared and 'liked' nearly 3,000 times. 
Official Home Office advice to tourists in Russia warns that petty crime, muggings and thefts are rife in cities. 
The threat of terrorism also remains ‘high’, according to the Home Office. Like us on Facebook
